linkTarget.anchoringText: The most important reservoir is the Morichal member (it contains 75 % of STOIIP). It is divided informally into lower, middle and upper units. The main depositional system in the Morichal member is fluvial-deltaic. The dominant reservoir facies in Morichal member are meandering and braided fluvial channels sandstones, which form stacked reservoir layers up to 300 ft thick separated by sealing shales. Each layer has good internal connectivity (Briceno et al., 1998; Dusseault et al., 2008; Santos, 1991; Yannimaras et al., 2006). Figure 1 shows the log response and reservoir zonation in an example well for this field.

The area for the pilot test was selected base on a reservoir quality index (Molina et al., 2009), representing the potential for thermal EOR technologies. The proposed approach is to drill all the wells in the Morichal Lower unit, which is the member with more sand continuity and better reservoir properties in average. Figure 2 shows the distribution of the quality index in the reservoir, and the location of the selected well pads in the better area (red color).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Distribution of the thermal EOR quality index and location of the pilot area

formatted-caption.caption-text: Distribution of the thermal EOR quality index and location of the pilot area

linkTarget.anchoringText: Well pad O-05-02 is asymmetrical, with longer wells (4,500 ft) in the left side than in the right side (2,200 ft). Well pad N-05-01 is crossed by one of the main fault in the zone. Right side wells are longer (3,000-3,300 ft) than the left side wells (2,000-3,300 ft). In both well pads the well distance is 300 m. The wellheads are located in the center of the well pad. Figure 3 shows the lay out of the wells in the two well pads selected for the CSS pilot test, O-05-02 and N-05-01.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Wells lay out in the two well pads selected

formatted-caption.caption-text: Wells lay out in the two well pads selected

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 4 shows the well pad O-05-02 finally selected for the CSS pilot test, with the coded specific steam flowrates to be injected in each well following the design of experiments, and their respectives lengths. Ordinal numbers to the right and left sides show the proposed steam injection sequence.

The CSS pilot test proposed considers 3 complete cycles. So, taking into account the previous 4 years of cold production, the total duration of the CSS pilot test should be about 11 years. Figure 5 shows the schematic planning for the whole CSS pilot test, implemented in well pad O-05-02.

Due to the CSS nature (a single well for injection and production), two different types of upper completions will be used. Figure 6 shows the schematic drawing for the injection stage. It consists of a pre-insulated tubing to reduce the heat losses, with a metal to metal seal.

For the production stage, it will have a tubing string with a metal to metal progressive cavity pump (PCP). Additionally, it is recommended to install a downhole gas separator at the pump inlet, to increase the pump efficiency. Figure 7 shows the schematic drawing for the production stage.

The pilot test surface facilities should treat the hot production in such a way that it could be sent againg to the CPF under the original design specifications. Figure 8 shows the surface facilities flow diagram proposed for the CSS pilot test.

A very detailed monitoring plan, supported by reservoir simulation studies, has been generated, taking into account state-of-the-art monitoring technologies, with the objective to capture the most important parameters to assess this pilot test. Figure 9 shows the proposed monitoring technologies.
The selected monitoring parameters are classified in three categories as follows, shown in Figure 10:

Figure 11 shows some operating parameters for the whole CSS pilot duration in the 2,200 ft long well, i.e., cold production liquid rate, hot production liquid rate, hot production oil rate, BHP, and average reservoir pressure.
Cumulative oil cold production vs cumulative oil CSS production is shown in Figure 12, for the 2,200 ft long well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Cold production vs hot production. 2,200 ft single well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cold production vs hot production. 2,200 ft single well

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 13 shows some operating parameters for the whole CSS pilot duration in the 4,500 ft long well, i.e., cold production liquid rate, hot production liquid rate, hot production oil rate, BHP, and average reservoir pressure.
Cumulative oil cold production vs cumulative oil CSS production is shown in Figure 14, for the 4,500 ft long well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Cold production vs hot production. 4,500 ft single well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cold production vs hot production. 4,500 ft single well

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 15 shows cumulative steam injection for the whole well pad. It can be distinguished first a period without steam injection (cold production), followed by three consecutive steam injection cycles.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative steam injection. Well pad O-05-02

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative steam injection. Well pad O-05-02

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 16 shows the oil rate for the cold production and the CSS production. During the cold production stage both lines coincide. During the hot production stage three large peaks can be seen, one for each cycle. For each peak, the shut in of the wells to be steam-injected and the successive wells opening can be perceived.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Oil rate in cold production vs hot production. Well pad O-05-02

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil rate in cold production vs hot production. Well pad O-05-02

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 17 shows the produced gas oil ratio (GOR), and the average reservoir pressure. An increase in GOR for the successive cycles of hot production can be seen. To be highlighted the higher increase in GOR due the average reservoir pressure decline, favored in this case by the increase in reservoir temperature after three CSS cycles.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: GOR and average reservoir pressure. Well pad O-05-02

formatted-caption.caption-text: GOR and average reservoir pressure. Well pad O-05-02

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 18 shows the produced water cut. Several narrow peaks can be observed, each one representing the production water increase in the hot production stage for the individual wells, after the soaking period.

Figure 19 shows cumulative oil production in both, cold production and CSS production, for the whole CSS pilot test. During the cold production stage both lines coincide. The difference between both lines at the end of the pilot test is called incremental cumulative oil production. A summary of the more significant parameters for the whole CSS pilot test are shown in the chart below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative cold production vs CSS production, and main CSS parameters. Well pad O-05-02

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative cold production vs CSS production, and main CSS parameters. Well pad O-05-02
